history.narrative: Law 12-104, the “Procurement Reform Amendment Act of 1998,” was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 12-363, which was referred to the Committee on Government Operations. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on December 4, 1997, and January 6, 1998, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on February 3, 1998, it was assigned Act No. 12-280 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 12-104 became effective on May 8, 1998.

Fiscal impact statement. The Council projects a positive fiscal impact for Bill 12-363. Section 2 establishes strong penalties to deter and punish fraudulent claims. It also establishes incentives for District employees to document and report false claims. The dollar value of these incentives cannot be estimated precisely, but it should be substantial in a government that purchases more than $600 million in goods and services annually. In addition, the false claims and qui tam provisions in Section 2 of Bill 12-363 would be essentially self-funding In any case successfully prosecuted by the Corporation Counsel, the violator would have to reimburse the District for the legal costs of the case. In addition, violators would be liable for treble damages and civil penalties of $5,000 to $10,000 for each false claim. After the payment of any award to a qui tam plaintiff and the restitution of the actual loss to the agency subject to the false claim, the District would deposit the proceeds into a Antifraud Fund with assets of up to $2 million available to pay for the enforcement of the law by the Corporation Counsel. Any additional funds recovered would be deposited in the District’s General Fund. Section 3 of Bill 12-363 makes only technical changes in the procurement code and would not have a fiscal impact. Section 4 of Bill 12-363 would have a strong and positive fiscal impact, because it would allow the District to renegotiate existing leases to lower rental rates and increase tenant allowances; terminate leases for unused or inefficient space; and consolidate underutilized space through space planning and subletting. Based on different assumptions, the Council estimates that the District should be able to reduce its annual rental cost of approximately $40 million by $2 million to $10 million annually. The lower cost saving figure will be achieved if the District reduces its average per square foot rate by 5 percent. The higher estimate will be achieved if the District reduces the average cost per square foot by 5 percent and reduces the amount of space by 21 percent. The report of the District’s Real Estate Executive Committee, as well as the studies by Arthur Anderson LLP, the consultant hired by the Financial Responsibility and Management Assistance Authority, indicates that these estimates are reasonable. 19 ENROLLED ORIGINAL Sec. 6.
